message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Quantifying the local adaptive landscape of a nascent bacterial community
Paper Abstract: Abstract The fitness effects of all possible mutations available to an organism largely shape the dynamics of evolutionary adaptation. Yet, whether and how this adaptive landscape changes over evolutionary times, especially upon ecological diversification and changes in community composition, remains poorly understood. We sought to fill this gap by analyzing a stable community of two closely related ecotypes (“L” and “S”) shortly after they emerged within the E. coli Long-Term Evolution Experiment (LTEE). We engineered genome-wide barcoded transposon libraries to measure the invasion fitness effects of all possible gene knockouts in the coexisting strains as well as their ancestor, for many different, ecologically relevant conditions. We find consistent statistical patterns of fitness effect variation across both genetic background and community composition, despite the idiosyncratic behavior of individual knockouts. Additionally, fitness effects are correlated with evolutionary outcomes for a number of conditions, possibly revealing shifting patterns of adaptation. Together, our results reveal how ecological and epistatic effects combine to shape the adaptive landscape in a nascent ecological community.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the search results for "community composition ecology":

## Overview

Community structure is the composition of the community. More broadly, in ecology, a community is a group or association of populations of two or more different species occupying the same geographical area at the same time.

## Community Ecology

Community ecology is the branch of ecology that studies interactions between and among species. It considers how such interactions, along with interactions between species and the abiotic environment, affect social structure and species richness, diversity and patterns of abundance.

## Factors Influencing Community Composition

Varying environmental conditions and each species' probability of arriving and becoming established along the gradient influence the community composition.(no content)The components of each plant community are influenced by soil type, topography, climate and human disturbance.

## Ecological Communities in Nature

The two main types of ecological communities are major communities, which are self-sustaining and self-regulating (such as a forest or a lake), and minor communities, which rely on other communities (like fungi decomposing a log) and are the building blocks of major communities.

## Theories of Community Composition

There are different theoretical perspectives on community composition. In phytosociology and community ecology an association is a type of ecological community with a predictable species composition and consistent physiognomy (structural appearance) which occurs in a particular habitat type.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Varying environmental conditions and each species' probability of arriving and becoming established along the gradient influence the community composition.(no content)The components of each plant community are influenced by soil type, topography, climate and human disturbance.

## Ecological Communities in Nature

The two main types of ecological communities are major communities, which are self-sustaining and self-regulating (such as a forest or a lake), and minor communities, which rely on other communities (like fungi decomposing a log) and are the building blocks of major communities.

## Theories of Community Composition

There are different theoretical perspectives on community composition. In phytosociology and community ecology an association is a type of ecological community with a predictable species composition and consistent physiognomy (structural appearance) which occurs in a particular habitat type.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "ecological diversification"

Links: [{"title":"Ecosystem diversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecosystem_diversity"},{"title":"Redonda (butterfly) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redonda_(genus)"},{"title":"Ecosystem service - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecosystem_services;"},{"title":"Réunion National Park - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/R%C3%A9union_National_Park"}]

Here are the search results for "ecological diversification":

## Overview of Ecological Diversification

Ecological diversity includes the variation in both terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems, and can take into account the variation in the complexity of a biological community, including the number of different niches and other ecological processes.(no content)Examples of ecological diversity on a global scale include the variation in ecosystems, such as deserts, forests, grasslands, wetlands and oceans.

## Evolutionary Drivers

Ecological diversity around the world can be directly linked to the evolutionary and selective pressures that constrain the diversity outcome of the ecosystems within different niches.(no content)Tundras, rainforests, coral reefs and deciduous forests are formed as a result of evolutionary pressures, and even seemingly small evolutionary interactions can have large impacts on the diversity of ecosystems throughout the world.

## Examples of Diversification

The search results include specific examples of how ecological diversification occurs. Island isolation and diversity of habitats and microclimates can favor the diversification of highly endemic flora. Additionally, rough topography can allow for the allopatric speciation of many bird species and genetic differentiation within those species.

## Role in Ecosystem Stability

The portfolio effect in biodiversity shows that diversification minimizes the risk of instability of ecosystem services through response diversity, where a suite of species exhibit differential responses to environmental perturbation, creating a stabilizing function that preserves the integrity of a service.

Links: [{"title":"Fitness landscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitness_landscape"},{"title":"Evolutionary landscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_landscape"},{"title":"Shifting balance theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shifting_balance_theory"},{"title":"Landscape genomics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Landscape_genomics"},{"title":"Evolvability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolvability"},{"title":"The Architect's Newspaper - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Architect's_Newspaper"},{"title":"Metadynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metadynamics"},{"title":"Elizabeth K. Meyer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elizabeth_K._Meyer"},{"title":"BYD Destroyer 05 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BYD_Destroyer_05"},{"title":"Landscape genetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Landscape_genetics"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about adaptive landscapes:

## Definition and Concept

In evolutionary biology, fitness landscapes or adaptive landscapes (types of evolutionary landscapes) are used to visualize the relationship between genotypes and reproductive success.(no content)In all fitness landscapes, height represents and is a visual metaphor for fitness.

## Key Features

Fitness landscapes are often conceived of as ranges of mountains. There exist local peaks (points from which all paths are downhill, i.e. to lower fitness) and valleys (regions from which many paths lead uphill).(no content)A fitness landscape with many local peaks surrounded by deep valleys is called rugged.

## Evolution and Movement

An evolving population typically climbs uphill in the fitness landscape, by a series of small genetic changes, until – in the infinite time limit – a local optimum is reached.

## Dynamic Nature

An important extension of the basic concept is the fitness seascape. Fitness seascapes extend the static fitness-landscape model by allowing the adaptive topography to shift through time or across changing environments. Rather than a fixed topography, seascapes describe adaptive surfaces whose peaks and valleys change in time as selection pressures evolve, producing trajectories that resemble dynamic "seascapes" rather than static landscapes.

The adaptive landscape remains a central metaphor in evolutionary biology for understanding how populations adapt and evolve over time.

Web search results for query: "mutation genetics"

Links: [{"title":"Mutation (genetic algorithm) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutation_(genetic_algorithm)"},{"title":"Mutation rate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutation_rate"},{"title":"Mutation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutation"},{"title":"De novo mutation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_novo_mutation"},{"title":"Deletion (genetics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deletion_(genetics)"},{"title":"Suppressor mutation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suppressor_mutation"},{"title":"Transition (genetics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transition_(genetics)"},{"title":"Polar mutation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polar_mutation"},{"title":"Carney triad - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carney_triad"},{"title":"Genetics of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetics_of_amyotrophic_lateral_sclerosis"}]

I've performed a web search for "mutation genetics" and found comprehensive information about the topic. Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Definition of Mutation

In biology, a mutation is an alteration in the nucleic acid sequence of the genome of an organism, virus, or extrachromosomal DNA.(no content)Mutations result from errors during DNA or viral replication, mitosis, or meiosis or other types of damage to DNA (such as pyrimidine dimers caused by exposure to ultraviolet radiation), which then may undergo error-prone repair.

## Causes and Effects

Mutations may or may not produce detectable changes in the observable characteristics (phenotype) of an organism. Mutations play a part in both normal and abnormal biological processes including evolution, cancer, and the development of the immune system.(no content)Mutations in genes can have no effect, alter the product of a gene, or prevent the gene from functioning properly or completely.

## Mutation Rates

In genetics, the mutation rate is the frequency of new mutations in a single gene, nucleotide sequence, or organism over time.(no content)Mutation rates are not constant and are not limited to a single type of mutation; there are many different types of mutations.

## Types of Mutations

Point mutations are a class of mutations that are changes to a single base. Missense, nonsense, and synonymous mutations are three subtypes of point mutations.(no content)A transition, in genetics and molecular biology, refers to a point mutation that changes a purine nucleotide to another purine (A ↔ G), or a pyrimidine nucleotide to another pyrimidine (C ↔ T).

## Evolutionary Significance

Mutation is the ultimate source of all genetic variation, providing the raw material on which evolutionary forces such as natural selection can act.

I've performed a web search for "mutation genetics" and found comprehensive information about the topic. Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Definition of Mutation

In biology, a mutation is an alteration in the nucleic acid sequence of the genome of an organism, virus, or extrachromosomal DNA.(no content)Mutations result from errors during DNA or viral replication, mitosis, or meiosis or other types of damage to DNA (such as pyrimidine dimers caused by exposure to ultraviolet radiation), which then may undergo error-prone repair.

## Causes and Effects

Mutations may or may not produce detectable changes in the observable characteristics (phenotype) of an organism. Mutations play a part in both normal and abnormal biological processes including evolution, cancer, and the development of the immune system.(no content)Mutations in genes can have no effect, alter the product of a gene, or prevent the gene from functioning properly or completely.

## Mutation Rates

In genetics, the mutation rate is the frequency of new mutations in a single gene, nucleotide sequence, or organism over time.(no content)Mutation rates are not constant and are not limited to a single type of mutation; there are many different types of mutations.

## Types of Mutations

Point mutations are a class of mutations that are changes to a single base. Missense, nonsense, and synonymous mutations are three subtypes of point mutations.(no content)A transition, in genetics and molecular biology, refers to a point mutation that changes a purine nucleotide to another purine (A ↔ G), or a pyrimidine nucleotide to another pyrimidine (C ↔ T).

## Evolutionary Significance

Mutation is the ultimate source of all genetic variation, providing the raw material on which evolutionary forces such as natural selection can act.

Links: [{"title":"Epistasis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistasis"},{"title":"Epistasis and functional genomics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistasis_and_functional_genomics"},{"title":"Additive genetic effects - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Additive_genetic_effects"},{"title":"Labrador Retriever coat colour genetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labrador_Retriever_coat_colour_genetics"},{"title":"Population genetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_genetics"},{"title":"Polygene - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polygene"},{"title":"Hypostatic gene - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypostatic_gene"},{"title":"Punnett square - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punnett_square"},{"title":"Association mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_mapping"},{"title":"Inclusive composite interval mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inclusive_composite_interval_mapping"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of epistasis in genetics:

## Definition

Epistasis is a phenomenon in genetics in which the effect of a gene mutation is dependent on the presence or absence of mutations in one or more other genes, respectively termed modifier genes.(no content)In other words, the effect of the mutation is dependent on the genetic background in which it appears.

## Historical Context

The term was first used in 1907 by William Bateson and his collaborators Florence Durham and Muriel Wheldale Onslow.

## Types of Epistasis

When the double mutation has a fitter phenotype than expected from the effects of the two single mutations, it is referred to as positive epistasis. Positive epistasis between beneficial mutations generates greater improvements in function than expected. Positive epistasis between deleterious mutations protects against the negative effects to cause a less severe fitness drop.

Conversely, when two mutations together lead to a less fit phenotype than expected from their effects when alone, it is called negative epistasis.

## Practical Example

Multiple genes react synergistically to affect a single trait. A classic example is found in Labrador Retrievers, where the ability of the E locus to override the coat colour directed by the B locus is a classical example of epistasis, where multiple genetic loci affect the same observed trait.

## Importance in Genetics

Systematic analysis of these epistatic interactions can provide insight into the structure and function of genetic pathways.

Links: [{"title":"Transposon mutagenesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transposon_mutagenesis"},{"title":"Transposon sequencing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transposon_sequencing"},{"title":"Mutagenesis (molecular biology technique) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutagenesis_(molecular_biology_technique)"},{"title":"Transposons as a genetic tool - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transposons_as_a_genetic_tool"},{"title":"Genome survey sequence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genome_survey_sequence"},{"title":"Transposable element - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transposable_element"},{"title":"Anton Berns - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anton_Berns"},{"title":"Site-directed mutagenesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Site-directed_mutagenesis"},{"title":"P element - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/P_element"},{"title":"Fine structure genetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fine_structure_genetics"}]

Here's what I found about transposon mutagenesis:

## Definition and Mechanism

Transposon mutagenesis, or transposition mutagenesis, is a biological process that allows genes to be transferred to a host organism's chromosome, interrupting or modifying the function of an extant gene on the chromosome and causing mutation.

## Advantages and Disadvantages

Transposon mutagenesis is much more effective than chemical mutagenesis, with a higher mutation frequency and a lower chance of killing the organism.(no content)Other advantages include being able to induce single hit mutations, being able to incorporate selectable markers in strain construction, and being able to recover genes after mutagenesis. However, disadvantages include the low frequency of transposition in living systems, and the inaccuracy of most transposition systems.

## Historical Background

Transposon mutagenesis was first studied by Barbara McClintock in the mid-20th century during her Nobel Prize-winning work with corn.

## Applications

Transposon mutagenesis has several important applications, including:
- Virulence genes in viruses and bacteria can be discovered by disrupting genes and observing for a change in phenotype, which has importance in antibiotic production and disease control.
- Non-essential genes can be discovered by inducing transposon mutagenesis in an organism, and because the organism survived after homologous integration, the interrupted gene was clearly non-essential.
- Cancer-causing genes can be identified by genome-wide mutagenesis and screening of mutants containing tumours, and based on the mechanism and results of the mutation, cancer-causing genes can be identified as oncogenes or tumour-suppressor genes.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the Long-Term Evolution Experiment (LTEE):

## Overview

The E. coli long-term evolution experiment (LTEE) is an ongoing study in experimental evolution begun by Richard Lenski at the University of California, Irvine, carried on by Lenski and colleagues at Michigan State University, and currently overseen by Jeffrey Barrick at the University of Texas at Austin.

## Duration and Scale

The experiment has been tracking genetic changes in 12 initially identical populations of asexual Escherichia coli bacteria since 24 February 1988.(no content)In August 2024, the LTEE populations passed 80,000 generations in the Barrick lab.

## Key Findings

The most notable adaptation reported so far is the evolution of aerobic growth on citrate, which is unusual in E. coli, in one population at some point between generations 31,000 and 31,500. Additionally, half of the populations have evolved defects in DNA repair that have caused phenotypes marked by elevated mutation rates.

## Current Status

The populations reached over 73,000 generations in early 2020, shortly before being frozen because of the COVID-19 pandemic. In September 2020, the LTEE experiment was resumed using the frozen stocks.(no content)In 2025, Barrick was hired by the Michigan State University Department of Microbiology, Genetics, and Immunology as a Hannah Distinguished Professor. In August of that year, his lab moved to MSU, bringing the LTEE back to Michigan.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "gene knockout"

Links: [{"title":"Gene knockout - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene_knockout"},{"title":"Conditional gene knockout - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conditional_gene_knockout"},{"title":"Gene knock-in - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene_knock-in"},{"title":"Knockout mouse - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knockout_mouse"},{"title":"Gene knockdown - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene_knockdown"},{"title":"DMRT1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DMRT1"},{"title":"// - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk%3AGene_knockout"},{"title":"Gene silencing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene_silencing"},{"title":"Martin Hrabě de Angelis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Hrab%C4%95_de_Angelis"},{"title":"Knockout moss - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knockout_moss"}]

## Gene Knockout

Gene knockouts (also known as gene deletion or gene inactivation) are a widely used genetic engineering technique that involves the targeted removal or inactivation of a specific gene within an organism's genome.(no content)This can be done through a variety of methods, including homologous recombination, CRISPR-Cas9, and TALENs.

### Purpose and Applications

One of the main advantages of gene knockouts is that they allow researchers to study the function of a specific gene in vivo, and to understand the role of the gene in normal development and physiology as well as in the pathology of diseases.(no content)Examples of research in which knockout mice have been useful include studying and modeling different kinds of cancer, obesity, heart disease, diabetes, arthritis, substance abuse, anxiety, aging and Parkinson's disease.

### Types

There are two main types of gene knockouts: complete and conditional. A complete gene knockout permanently inactivates the gene, while a conditional gene knockout allows for the gene to be turned off and on at specific times or in specific tissues.(no content)Conditional gene knockout is a technique used to eliminate a specific gene in a certain tissue, such as the liver.

### Limitations

Gene knockouts also have some limitations. For example, the loss of a single gene may not fully mimic the effects of a genetic disorder, and the knockouts may have unintended effects on other genes or pathways.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "E. coli Escherichia coli"

Links: [{"title":"Escherichia coli - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escherichia_coli"},{"title":"Escherichia coli O157:H7 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escherichia_coli_O157:H7"},{"title":"Escherichia - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escherichia"},{"title":"Pathogenic Escherichia coli - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pathogenic_Escherichia_coli"},{"title":"Escherichia coli in molecular biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escherichia_coli_in_molecular_biology"},{"title":"Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enterotoxigenic_Escherichia_coli"},{"title":"Coliform bacteria - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coliform_bacteria"},{"title":"Enteroaggregative Escherichia coli - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enteroaggregative_Escherichia_coli"},{"title":"Enterobacteriaceae - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enterobacteriaceae"},{"title":"List of strains of Escherichia coli - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_strains_of_Escherichia_coli"}]

Here's what I found about E. coli (Escherichia coli):

## Basic Overview

Escherichia coli is a gram-negative, facultative anaerobic, rod-shaped, coliform bacterium of the genus Escherichia that is commonly found in the lower intestine of warm-blooded organisms.

## Normal vs. Pathogenic Strains

Most E. coli strains are part of the normal gut microbiota and are harmless. However, some strains develop traits that can be harmful to a host animal. These virulent strains typically cause a bout of diarrhea that is often self-limiting in healthy adults but is frequently lethal to children in the developing world.(no content)More virulent strains, such as O157:H7, cause serious illness or death in the elderly, the very young, or the immunocompromised.

## Laboratory Use

E. coli K-12 and E. coli B strains are the most frequently used varieties for laboratory purposes.(no content)The bacterium can also be grown easily and inexpensively in a laboratory setting, and has been intensively investigated for over 60 years. E. coli is the most widely studied prokaryotic model organism, and an important species in the fields of biotechnology and microbiology, where it has served as the host organism for the majority of work with recombinant DNA.

## Genome

The first complete DNA sequence of an E. coli genome (laboratory strain K-12 derivative MG1655) was published in 1997. It is a circular DNA molecule 4.6 million base pairs in length, containing 4288 annotated protein-coding genes (organized into 2584 operons), seven ribosomal RNA (rRNA) operons, and 86 transfer RNA (tRNA) genes.

It is a circular DNA molecule 4.6 million base pairs in length, containing 4288 annotated protein-coding genes (organized into 2584 operons), seven ribosomal RNA (rRNA) operons, and 86 transfer RNA (tRNA) genes.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of DNA barcoding in molecular biology:

## What is DNA Barcoding?

DNA barcoding uses specific short DNA sequences or markers from a standardized region of the genome to provide a DNA barcode for identifying species.(no content)DNA barcoding involves specific targeting of gene regions that are found and conserved in most animal species, but have high variation between members of different species.

## Historical Background

Barcoding was proposed in 2003 by Prof. Paul Hebert of the University of Guelph as a way of distinguishing and identifying species with a short standardized gene sequence, with Hebert proposing the 658 bases of the Folmer region of the mitochondrial gene cytochrome-C oxidase-1 as the standard barcode region.

## Applications

Applications of DNA barcoding include identification of new species, safety assessment of food, identification and assessment of cryptic species, detection of alien species, identification of endangered and threatened species, linking egg and larval stages to adult species, securing intellectual property rights for bioresources, framing global management plans for conservation strategies, and forensic science.

## Key Databases

The Barcode of Life Data System (BOLD), launched in 2007, is one of the biggest databases, containing about 780,000 BINs (Barcode Index Numbers) in 2022, and is a freely accessible repository for specimen and sequence records for barcode studies.

DNA barcoding has become an essential tool in molecular biology for species identification across diverse organisms including animals, plants, fungi, and microorganisms.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

The paper proposes a novel experimental approach using genome-wide barcoded transposon libraries to measure fitness effects across multiple strains and ecological contexts.

**Key Triples Extracted (11 total):**

1. **Fitness landscape** (concept, uses) - Core theoretical framework for understanding adaptive evolution
2. **Mutation** (concept, uses) - Central to analyzing fitness effects
3. **Fitness (biology)** (concept, uses) - Primary measurement in the study
4. **Ecosystem diversity** (concept, uses) - Framework for ecological diversification
5. **Community (ecology)** (concept, uses) - Studies community composition effects
6. **Escherichia coli** (artifact, uses) - Model organism from the LTEE
7. **E. coli long-term evolution experiment** (data, uses) - Source dataset/context
8. **Gene knockout** (method, uses) - Experimental technique for creating knockouts
9. **Transposon mutagenesis** (method, uses) - Technology for systematic mutagenesis
10. **Epistasis** (concept, uses) - Genetic interaction framework
11. **DNA barcoding** (method, proposes) - Novel contribution: genome-wide barcoded libraries

✅ **Validation Status:** All checks passed successfully!

Sources:
- [Fitness landscape](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitness_landscape)
- [Mutation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutation)
- [Fitness (biology)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitness_(biology))
- [Ecosystem diversity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecosystem_diversity)
- [Community (ecology)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Community_(ecology))
- [Escherichia coli](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escherichia_coli)
